BASEBALL SCHEDULE EXCELLENT

PENNSYLVANIA BEATS HOPKINS

-- Prospects for Successful Season Bright
— 8 of Last Year's Team Back
Armstrong to Coach.

Local Swimmers Good Runners Up in I Herbert C. Hoover to Speak at Celebration of 44th Year Since OpenEvery Event But Total Score 42-11
ing of John Hopkins.
—Shields is Star of Meet.

Lack of Team Work Displayed by Hopkins Basketeers—F reshmen Defcat
Poly in Preliminary Game.

The forty-fourth anniversary of
the opening of the Johns Hopkins
University will be publicly observed on Monday, February 23,
in the Lyric Theatre. The principal speaker will be the Hon. Herbert C. Hoover, LL. D.
Arrangements for the exercises
are-as follows:
The trustees and faculty will
assemble at 10 o'clock in the hall
over the main lobby. The official
guests are invited to join the academic procession at 10 o'clock in
the same place. Those who may
prefer to go directly to the auditorium will be provided with seats
on the main floor (right) upon
showing their cards to the ushers.
The alumni will assemble at 10
o'clock in the lower hall on Maryland avenue, whence they will proceed to reserved seats in the auditorium. The students will meet
at 9.45 o'clock in the same room,
and will proceed, under the direction of their marshals, to the seats
reserved for them.
The procession will enter the
auditorium at 10.15 o'clock. The
boxes will be reserved until this
hour for the families of the trustees and faculty, and the seats on
the first floor not required for
those in the procession for other
persons holding cards. After the
procession has entered, the remaining seats will be free to the
public. A portion of the balcony
will also be reserved for ticket
holders until 10.15 o'clock. The
exercises will begin punctually at
10.30 o'clock and will close probably before 12.30. It would seem hardly necessary
to emphasize the fact that every
undergraduate is expected to be
present at this memorable occasion; for the celebrity of the principal speaker should.constitute in
itself enough drawing-power even
were there ribt the further consideration of college spirit. The
Uni,yersity is 'Certainly fortunate
in being able to have Herbert C.
Hoover, one of the best-known
men in ,the world today, as the
chief orator at the observation of
the forty-fourth anniversary of
her birth. Needless to say punctuality will be necessary in coming
to the Lyric. The audience will
undoubtedly fill the building to
overflowing despite its size, and so
to procure a seat within good
hearing distance, students must
arrive promptly at 9.45.

In a fast, hard-played game, the
Johns Hopkins basketeers fell before the onslaughts of the Princeton quintet. The superior physical
condition and greater stamina of
the Orange and Black told in the
long run, for in the first half Hopkins played them to a standstill.
However, when the second period
was called, it was plainly evident
what the outcome, which had
hitherto been uncertain, would be,
as the local boys showed their exhaustion plainly. Princeton, on
the other hand, sent in several
fresh men and the score piled up.
The only thing that marred a
perfect exhibition of basket-ball
was the long shooting on the part
of Weiner and, to some extent, of
Cuneo. This fault is the one
which Coach Murphy has been
combatting throughout the season
without being able to overcome.
The first half was replete with
thrills. Hopkins jumped off at
the whistle,. running up three
points before Princeton awoke.
Three fouls on the part of Hopkins followed in quick succession,
two of which Netts put through
the hoop. Immediately after,
Netts scored a difficult goal and
the visitors were ahead. Pretty
teamwork of Flinn and Weiner resulted in a basket and Hopkins
once more forged ahead, to hold
this lead till near the end of the
half, when Princeton made a rally
and chalked up four baskets. The
half ended with the Tigers at the
fat half of a 13-9 score.
The second half was a sad affair for Hopkins' supporters.
Princeton played all around the
local boys, scoring almost at will.
Netts had the edge_on Cuneo in
the foul shooting, netting six baskets out of nine tries, as opposed
to three out of seven on the part
of the Black and Blue guard.
On the defensive play, time
Orange and Black far outshone
the local basketeers. When a
Hopkins player got his hands on
the ball he was almost invariably
confronted by the problem of
working the leather through the
entire Princeton team, while many
times three of the visitors would
tear down the floor with but one
Black and Blue warrior to hinder
them.
In the preliminary contest, the
Hopkins freshmen had no trouble
in trouncing the Poly quint to the
tune of 14-4. Aaronson outshone
all his team-mates on the offense,

The Johns Hopkins baseball
team will assume this spring the
hardest and largest schedule
which any Hopkins nine has ever
undertaken. Manager Field has
arranged games with the country's foremost collegiate baseball
teams, such as Holy Cross, Fordham, I'rinceton, Cornell, Tufts,
etc. Easter week will open the
season with an even half dozen
diamond battles, the first of which
will be with Priceton. Three extensive trips will be made by the
team, one to southern climes to
tackle the University of Virginia
in her lair, and two northern colleges. The first, of a week's duration, will be undertaken the last
week in April, on which excursion
Fordham, Crescents, Columbia
and Stevens will be met. At present, Manager Fields has only two
games on the card for the second
trip, which will take place at the
end of the collegiate year, those
with Boston College and Lehigh,
but he has negotiations under way
with several other universities.
That the management feels safe
in binding the nine to such a rigorous contract seems to be wellgrounded, although nothing certain can be said at this date.
However, everything points to a
very successful season, as the entire last year's team, with the exception of Judefind, the star
twirler, will be found in uniform
once more. Juclefind's place will
be well _filled, however, as "Ted"
Welliver and "Bobby" Owings, as
well as several new candidates,
will adorn the mound for the
Black and Blue this season. Welliver, it will be remembered, carried off all the pitching honors in
1918, but last year he contracted
the flu and was forced to leave
college. However, he is back this
season with bells on. "Bobby"
Owings, too, played in hard luck
last year. He hails from Friends
School, on which team he starred
for several years, but he was a
victim of the blacklist, and was
unable to don the uniform.
Wallace, a medico, who twirled
several games and led the team
with the stick last season, will be
on hand, ready to prove that he,
too, is in a class with Owings and
Welliver.
Herbert Armstrong, all-American inter-collegiate third baseman for two years, who has
coached City College for several
years, will guide the Black and
Blue through this spring. He will
(Continued on page 7, col. I)

The University of Pennsylvania
swimming team defeated the Hopkins representatives at the Baltimore Athletic Club on Saturday
night, February 14, by the large
score of 42-11. Although the local
swimmers failed to win a first
place, they forced the visitors to
exert themselves in every event.
Shields, of Penn, was easily the
star of the meet, setting a new
mark for the 220-yard swim and
equaling the record for the 100
yards. He also swam on the winning relay team.
The 40-yard dash was the closest
event. Although it was awarded
to Leopold, it looked very much
as though Davidge Rowland tied
him. Henry Rowland was also
not far in the rear of Shields in
the 100 yards.
In the plunge Pennsylvania
gained first and second places, although Boone, a new Hopkins
man, did well in reaching the 56foot mark in 47 seconds. With a
little practice he should easily
plunge the whole distance.
Pennsylvania was represented
in the fancy diving by Armstrong,
one of the best in the country. Although he won the event, "Toots"
Slingluff also had some very clever
and spectacular dives, and was a
very close second. Penn won the
relay by less than six feet, opening the meet with a real thrill.
In the exhibition back and
breast stroke matches, Hopkins
•
had little difficulty in gaining
both first and second places. In
the forMer event, "Bill" Reins
broke his own record of 28 seconds
for the 40 yards, cutting it down
to 2775, a new South Atlantic
mark.
Next Saturday Hopkins meets
Swarthmore and, according to the
present "dope," should have a fine
chance of coming out on top.
The summary:
160-Yard Relay—Won by Penn (Armstrong, Martyn, Leopold and Shields).
Time, 1 minute 23 1-5 seconds.
Plunge—Bursh (Penn), Kohler (Penn),
Boone (H). Sixty feet in 37 Freconls.
40-Yard Dash—Leopold (l'enn). Rowland
(H), Martyn (Penn). Time, 20 4-5 seconds.
220-Yard Swim—Shields (Penn), Bringhurst (Penn), Hall (II.). Time, 2 minutes
36 4-5 seconds.
Fancy Dive—Armstrong (Penn), Slingluff
(H), Wennert (Penn).
100-Yard Swim—Shields (Penn), H.
Rowland (H), Bringhurst (Penn). Time,
1 minute 4-5 seconds.
40-Yard Back Stroke—Reins (H), Hall
(II), Armstrong (Penn). Time, 27 1-5 seconds.
40-Yard Breast Stroke—D. Rowleend (H),
Aguado (H), Wennert (Penn). Time, 254-5
seconds.
Officials—Cogswell Tinkler, Burdick. .McCallister, Bruhuer, Baugher and Steer.

FEB. 17, 1920

Why Canes?

"The Senior Class is to carry
special and distinctive canes after
Easter." Needless to say, there
has been.quite a bit of comment
upon this venture into the field
of fantasy. Some have given forth
the merry guffaw, others have
shaken their heads sadly at the
latest signs of the mental depravity of our wisest and most venerable seekers after knowledge.
Both have missed the point of the
matter.
The real facts are these: By.
,adopting canes as their private
mark of fame, the Senior Class is
forging another link into our
chain of Hopkins tradition. The
cane itself has always carried a
certain air of distinction. Their
infrequency of use at the present
time is due perhaps to the rush
and hurry of the period. Our
Seniors will have, by then, almost
completed a period of study and of
student activity, and will have
become the leaders of the campus
life. The cane will be a most appropriate accompaniment to'their
dignity.
The spirit of an institution of
learning, or, as our army circles
put it, the morale, is directly proportioned to the student traditions. We have not been long at

Obituary.

Edgar A. Morgan, graduate
student in the Department of
Education, (lied of pneumonia on
February 5.
Koichi Morita, of Japan, a graduate student ill plant physiology,
botany and geology at this Uniersity, died suddenly at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital on Sunday,
February 8. Morita was a graduate of Tokio University and was
doing his second year's work at
Hopkins.
Dr. Livingston, professor of
plant physiology, considered him
a fine scholar, an indefatigable
worker and a thorough gentleman,
and says that he gave great promise of becoming a leader in botanical science. Morita's experimentation was in such shape that Dr.
Livingston and Mr. H. C. Diehl
plan to prepare a brief report of
the results of his experiments for
publication in the near future.
In the universities of South
America, subjects are commonly
studied only for a professional
end. The scholar studies natural
sciences only in the medical school
for their bearing on medicine, and
the social sciences only in the law
school for their bearing on jurisprudence. Hence the universities
generally contain only professional schools without any college of
liberal arts.
The United States is carrying
on two collossal experiments in
education. One is to conduct its
schools largely through the services of unmarried ladies who average three years' teaching before
they get married. The second is
to give education without religion.
The United States has yet to prove
that it will succeed in either or
both of these experiments.—Prof.
Sisson, University of Montana.

Thinks Hopkins is Dying of Dry Pot.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

February 14, 1920.
Sir—it was with extreme regret
that 1 heard of the resignation of
Dr. Slonimsky from the faculty
of the Department of Philosophy.
Helping to solve the greatest probkm before the country today—
that of labor—could not but make
a man more capable of bringing to
his classes a most valuable point
of view.
Universities have often been accused of being too secluded and
out of touch with the problems of
the world. Philosophy has lost
much of its erstwhile popularity
because it did not come in the
realm of "useful" studies. And
so when a professor who is combining practical work with his
teaching is allowed to resign it
appears inexcusable. The theory
of "splendid isolation" for universities is absurd.
Harvard is justifiably proud of
such of its men as Ripley, who has
been engaged in arbitrating labor
disputes for several years, and
Taussig, who has been called to
the Industrial Conference in
'Washington.
' Does Hopkins want only men
on its faculty who fit Shaw's characterization of a teacher: "A man
who can does, a man who can't
teaches." Or perhaps the powers
that be think that the faculty can
learn nothing except from the
books in the library.
I regard the fact that Dr. Slonimsky was not kept in the faculty on part time as another indication of what many of the
younger graduates believe—that
Hopkins has lost its traditional
vitality and is dying of dry rot.
Very truly yours,

A. L. HAMBURGER, 18.
Pleased With Editorials.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—I want to use a little of
your valuable space to express my
appreciation of your editorials.
One of their chief values is that
they are always very pertinent as
regards questionsdirectly affecting
Hopkins, and are always trying to
improve conditions that need
remedying. In BO many periodicals
of this kind the editorials are so
perfunctory that they are of little
• value. Your editorial on the Kessler petition deserves the commendation of every true Hopkins man.
E. R.
Yours sincerely,

QUACKS FROM A QUACK
Eurroa's Nom----George is very greatly
elated over the overwhelming success of
his own personal quack column, but he
fears that his sparkling and scintillating
satire is not received in the serious manner
In- which it is meant. He has, therefore,
applied • to THE NEWS-LETTER for permis• sion to preach a sermon in this week's
issue, and he sincerely hopes and trusts
that his efforts will not be in vain. Needless
to say his request was granted, and we submit for your approval a little talk by the
Rev. George Quack, D. 1).1

Brethren, if you may be termed
as such, I am going to take may
text this morning from the first
chapter of St. John, twenty-third
verse, "the voice of one crying in
the wilderness." The voice in
this case I take to .• be the poor
little innocent freshman who finds
himself deposited in the midst of
a large university, not knowing
which way to turn without encountering a soph's paddle. Just
a bit of advice to ye freshmen from
one who has been through the
mill and knows, you can't get any
more out of college life than you
put into it. Why, just the other
day Dr. Gilpin told me that
George Wagner's kid brother (I
can't think of his maiden name
right now) was in the midst of
making a concoction of silver nitrate by dissolving a dime in
nitric acid. "Doc," he says, "I
haven't got a dime, will two
nickels do?"
And then, freshmen, don't fool
away your precious hours of study
by going to the theatre- all the
time like Chauncey Wright does.
They tell me that he was summoned to his adviser not so long
ago to receive some paternal advice. "Lemme see your report,.
Mr. Wright," said Dr. Gilpin.
"Ahem, failed in two subjects,
didn't you? Damn pity you didn't
flunk in three, and then we
wouldn't have to bother with
you." Moral, don't do as I do,
do as I say should be did.
If you really and truly want to
make an honest-to-gosh success of
your college career commit some
crime worthy of publication in my
world-beating column. That done,
your fame is assured for generations to come; in other words, you
have burst into immortal print.
Like a little crowd of fellows in
Biology II have passed a bill
which states that the chap who
receives the lowest mark in a quiz
has to stand treat for the bunch.
For the last five times Mr. Frank
Smith has footed the bill, and for
this -unsurpassed record the other
biologists deem him worthy of a
little notoriety. They are right,
Mr. Smith; that, sir, is a deed
Worthy to place you before the
public eye.
. And in conclusion, let me tell
you, you didn't mind being paddled a bit for having your hands
in your pockets. To err is human
and to forgive divine, which goes
to prove that the sophomores are
not divine. Amen!

of speaking at Lexington for
Johns Hopkins. In this contest,
which will be held on March 5,
'he will meet the orators of six
representative southern universities, including our old rivals in
debate, the University of Virginia
and the University of North Carolina.

CLUB HAS GOOD REHEARSAL
"Pep" Displayed by Musical Club To
Give a Concert on February 27-28,
and on March the 19th.

The first rehearsal of the Musical Clubs since the examinations'
quarantine was held as usual in
the Civil Engineering Hall on
February 9. The attendance was
good and the men made a strong
attack on the music for the spring
concerts. "Shorty" Defandorf reported that the treasury is in a
healthy condition at present, but
will need a little "dosing" within
the next month.
Hartman put the Glee Club
through a grilling practice and
ended by telling them that it was
one of the best rehearsals of the
year. He was especially pleased
with the control of the modulation in "Annie Laurie," and even
the C. E. night janitor said that,
"all yah needed to do was to close
yah eyes, an'—oh, boy !"
The Instrumental Club will use
the piano and traps with their
numbers for the rest of the season. The addition makes a great
improvement all around.
With "Mike" Bowers tickling
the ivories, the jazz orchestra,
with a new set of traps. is "raising Cain." Paul Wiggins is showing how to jazz a ukulele, and
"Shorty" Rankin and Vanneman
make things hum. On the whole,
Coulter is turning out an Instrumental Club Mitch is making a•
name for itself.
A concert will be given on February 27 or 28. But just wait till
March 19! The concert that night
at Towson High School A'ill be followed by a dance, so get ready
Musical Club men.

FACULTY NOTES
Dr. Burton E. Livingston, pro
fessor of plant physiology, and
director of the laboratory of plant
life at the Johns Hopkins University, has recently been elected
permanent secretary of the AmeriCa 11 Association for the Advancelima of Science, to take the place
of Dr. L. 0. Howard, who resigned
to take the presidency. Professor
Livingston will continue his work
in the University and plans to
spend about two days a week in
Washington, where he has his
office in the Smithsonian Institution.
Prof. Livingston is a S. B. graduate of the University of Michigan, 1898; fellow, University of
Chicago, 1899-1902; Ph. D., 1902;
assistant in plant physiology,
1902-04, and associate, 1905; collaborator, U. S. Bureau of Forestry, 1902; research fellow, New
York Botanical Garden, 1903;
Walker prize man, Boston Society of Natural History, 1904; soil
expert, in charge of the Division
of Fertility, U. S. Bureau of Soils,
1904-05; staff member, Department of Botanical Research, Carnegie Institution of Washington,
1906-09.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 17,

SLINGLUFF BEST FANCY DIVER

MRS. SPEARE MAKES ADDRESS

Swimming Team Suffers Second Defeat
—Columbia Better by Overwhelming Score —Hopkins Gets
Only. One Place.

"Russian Dramatists" Subject of Her
Talk to Literary Club—Emphasizes
Influence of Russian School.

The second lecture of a series
given under the auspices Of the
Literary Club was held Friday
evening, February 6, in the Mechanical Engineering Hall. Florence Lewis Speare addressed the
club on "Russian Dramatists and
the Modern Russian Stage." Mrs.
Speare, who has just been elected
president of the Drama League of
Baltimore, was well qualified to
lecture. She is a graduate of
Prof. George Pierce Baker's Workshop Theatre of Harvard and at
present is director of dramatics
at Goucher College. Mrs. Speare
is a dramatic writer herself, and
the vivid, colorful choice of words
and the interesting manner of
presentation made her lecture admirable and instructive.
Mrs. Speare spoke of the Russian stage as the world's leading
theatre where "all the arts are
gathered together in a poem of
beauty." Before the rise of the
Russian influence, the stage, both
in Europe and America, consisted
very largely in the presentation
of elaborate realistic scenes, which
fed the senses and made no appeal
to the imagination or the intellect. Suddenly a change came;
symbolism of the stage was born.
It was an attempt to symbolize
the soul of the drama in the setting. It is this symbolism in the
"mise en scene" which the Russian spirit demands—a symbolism
which is Oriental in barbaric brilliancy, vivid in passionate emotion and rich in temperamental
analysis. As colorists the Russians lead. America was intro
duce(' to the Russian spirit and
mood by the Russian ballet.
Leon Baskt is chief in creating
the "mounting of the play." He
uses lights, colors and music as
symbols to further the atmosphere
of the play. He is "intellectualizing scenery." This school of stage
artists give freest expression to the
imagination. There is grotesque
opulence and fairy delicacy. The
drama has been revolutionized. It
is far more than words; it is
scenes of pictures and symphonies
•of sounds. All the arts have been
concentrated to produce the
drama as exemplified in Russia.
In 1825 Russian drama was
born through the repression of

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team suffered its second defeat of
the season when it met and lost to
the Columbia team by the score
of 39-14 in the Baltimore Athletic
Club on Friday night, February 6.
The home team was able to will
but one first place and two seconds. Such a decisive defeat was
entirely unexpected and is attributed to the fact that few of
the Hopkins men were able to
practice during the week on account of the mid-year examinations.
Charlie Slingluff starred for
Hopkins, experiencing but little
difficulty in defeating the Columbia men in the fancy dive. Mabie,,
of the vistitors, was second and
Call, of Hopkins, third in this
event.
The first event, the 160-yard relay, was taken by Columbia, with
plenty to spare at the end. Garrigus and Chrystal, of the visiting
team, finished first and second in
the 40-yard dash, with Davidge
Rowland close behind them. In
the 220 yards, Polk, of Columbia,
led from the start, while "Bod"
Hall nosed the other New Yorke
out for second honors. Henry
Rowland could not quite catch
Everhard in the 100-yard swim
and had to be satisfied with second
place. Bernard, also of Columbia,
was third in this event.
Columbia was represented by
two plungers as expert as any seen
in Baltimore this year in flinch
and Mahaar, both of whom made
the whole pool, 60 feet, in less
than 40 seconds. The former won
the event with the excellent time
of 39 seconds. Gould, of the home
team, was third.
rhe Hopkins team is scheduled
to meet the University of Pennsylvania swimmers at the Baltimore Athletic Club at 8 o'clock
next Saturday night, February 21.
With regular practices, several
times this week, Captain Hall expects to have his team in a condition to make a much better
showing of itself, although Pennsylvania is represented ,by some
of the most expert swimmers in
the country.

The forty-fourth anniversary of
the opening of the Johns Hopkins
University will be publicly observed on Monday, February 23,
in the Lyric Theatre. The principal speaker will be the Hon. Herbert C. Hoover, LL. D.
Arrangements for the exercises
are-as follows:
The trustees and faculty will
assemble at 10 o'clock in the hall
over the main lobby. The official
guests are invited to join the academic procession at 10 o'clock in
the same place. Those who may
prefer to go directly to the auditorium will be provided with seats
on the main floor (right) upon
showing their cards to the ushers.
The alumni will assemble at 10
o'clock in the lower hall on Maryland avenue, whence they will proceed to reserved seats in the auditorium. The students will meet
at 9.45 o'clock in the same room,
and will proceed, under the direction of their marshals, to the seats
reserved for them.
The procession will enter the
auditorium at 10.15 o'clock. The
boxes will be reserved until this
hour for the families of the trustees and faculty, and the seats on
the first floor not required for
those in the procession for other
persons holding cards. After the
procession has entered, the remaining seats will be free to the
public. A portion of the balcony
will also be reserved for ticket
holders until 10.15 o'clock. The
exercises will begin punctually at
10.30 o'clock and will close probably before 12.30. It would seem hardly necessary
to emphasize the fact that every
undergraduate is expected to be
present at this memorable occasion; for the celebrity of the principal speaker should.constitute in
itself enough drawing-power even
were there ribt the further consideration of college spirit. The
Uni,yersity is 'Certainly fortunate
in being able to have Herbert C.
Hoover, one of the best-known
men in ,the world today, as the
chief orator at the observation of
the forty-fourth anniversary of
her birth. Needless to say punctuality will be necessary in coming
to the Lyric. The audience will
undoubtedly fill the building to
overflowing despite its size, and so
to procure a seat within good
hearing distance, students must
arrive promptly at 9.45.

In a fast, hard-played game, the
Johns Hopkins basketeers fell before the onslaughts of the Princeton quintet. The superior physical
condition and greater stamina of
the Orange and Black told in the
long run, for in the first half Hopkins played them to a standstill.
However, when the second period
was called, it was plainly evident
what the outcome, which had
hitherto been uncertain, would be,
as the local boys showed their exhaustion plainly. Princeton, on
the other hand, sent in several
fresh men and the score piled up.
The only thing that marred a
perfect exhibition of basket-ball
was the long shooting on the part
of Weiner and, to some extent, of
Cuneo. This fault is the one
which Coach Murphy has been
combatting throughout the season
without being able to overcome.
The first half was replete with
thrills. Hopkins jumped off at
the whistle,. running up three
points before Princeton awoke.
Three fouls on the part of Hopkins followed in quick succession,
two of which Netts put through
the hoop. Immediately after,
Netts scored a difficult goal and
the visitors were ahead. Pretty
teamwork of Flinn and Weiner resulted in a basket and Hopkins
once more forged ahead, to hold
this lead till near the end of the
half, when Princeton made a rally
and chalked up four baskets. The
half ended with the Tigers at the
fat half of a 13-9 score.
The second half was a sad affair for Hopkins' supporters.
Princeton played all around the
local boys, scoring almost at will.
Netts had the edge_on Cuneo in
the foul shooting, netting six baskets out of nine tries, as opposed
to three out of seven on the part
of the Black and Blue guard.
On the defensive play, time
Orange and Black far outshone
the local basketeers. When a
Hopkins player got his hands on
the ball he was almost invariably
confronted by the problem of
working the leather through the
entire Princeton team, while many
times three of the visitors would
tear down the floor with but one
Black and Blue warrior to hinder
them.
In the preliminary contest, the
Hopkins freshmen had no trouble
in trouncing the Poly quint to the
tune of 14-4. Aaronson outshone
all his team-mates on the offense,

The Johns Hopkins baseball
team will assume this spring the
hardest and largest schedule
which any Hopkins nine has ever
undertaken. Manager Field has
arranged games with the country's foremost collegiate baseball
teams, such as Holy Cross, Fordham, I'rinceton, Cornell, Tufts,
etc. Easter week will open the
season with an even half dozen
diamond battles, the first of which
will be with Priceton. Three extensive trips will be made by the
team, one to southern climes to
tackle the University of Virginia
in her lair, and two northern colleges. The first, of a week's duration, will be undertaken the last
week in April, on which excursion
Fordham, Crescents, Columbia
and Stevens will be met. At present, Manager Fields has only two
games on the card for the second
trip, which will take place at the
end of the collegiate year, those
with Boston College and Lehigh,
but he has negotiations under way
with several other universities.
That the management feels safe
in binding the nine to such a rigorous contract seems to be wellgrounded, although nothing certain can be said at this date.
However, everything points to a
very successful season, as the entire last year's team, with the exception of Judefind, the star
twirler, will be found in uniform
once more. Juclefind's place will
be well _filled, however, as "Ted"
Welliver and "Bobby" Owings, as
well as several new candidates,
will adorn the mound for the
Black and Blue this season. Welliver, it will be remembered, carried off all the pitching honors in
1918, but last year he contracted
the flu and was forced to leave
college. However, he is back this
season with bells on. "Bobby"
Owings, too, played in hard luck
last year. He hails from Friends
School, on which team he starred
for several years, but he was a
victim of the blacklist, and was
unable to don the uniform.
Wallace, a medico, who twirled
several games and led the team
with the stick last season, will be
on hand, ready to prove that he,
too, is in a class with Owings and
Welliver.
Herbert Armstrong, all-American inter-collegiate third baseman for two years, who has
coached City College for several
years, will guide the Black and
Blue through this spring. He will

The University of Pennsylvania
swimming team defeated the Hopkins representatives at the Baltimore Athletic Club on Saturday
night, February 14, by the large
score of 42-11. Although the local
swimmers failed to win a first
place, they forced the visitors to
exert themselves in every event.
Shields, of Penn, was easily the
star of the meet, setting a new
mark for the 220-yard swim and
equaling the record for the 100
yards. He also swam on the winning relay team.
The 40-yard dash was the closest
event. Although it was awarded
to Leopold, it looked very much
as though Davidge Rowland tied
him. Henry Rowland was also
not far in the rear of Shields in
the 100 yards.
In the plunge Pennsylvania
gained first and second places, although Boone, a new Hopkins
man, did well in reaching the 56foot mark in 47 seconds. With a
little practice he should easily
plunge the whole distance.
Pennsylvania was represented
in the fancy diving by Armstrong,
one of the best in the country. Although he won the event, "Toots"
Slingluff also had some very clever
and spectacular dives, and was a
very close second. Penn won the
relay by less than six feet, opening the meet with a real thrill.
In the exhibition back and
breast stroke matches, Hopkins
•
had little difficulty in gaining
both first and second places. In
the forMer event, "Bill" Reins
broke his own record of 28 seconds
for the 40 yards, cutting it down
to 2775, a new South Atlantic
mark.
Next Saturday Hopkins meets
Swarthmore and, according to the
present "dope," should have a fine
chance of coming out on top.

Why Canes?

"The Senior Class is to carry
special and distinctive canes after
Easter." Needless to say, there
has been.quite a bit of comment
upon this venture into the field
of fantasy. Some have given forth
the merry guffaw, others have
shaken their heads sadly at the
latest signs of the mental depravity of our wisest and most venerable seekers after knowledge.
Both have missed the point of the
matter.
The real facts are these: By.
,adopting canes as their private
mark of fame, the Senior Class is
forging another link into our
chain of Hopkins tradition. The
cane itself has always carried a
certain air of distinction. Their
infrequency of use at the present
time is due perhaps to the rush
and hurry of the period. Our
Seniors will have, by then, almost
completed a period of study and of
student activity, and will have
become the leaders of the campus
life. The cane will be a most appropriate accompaniment to'their
dignity.
The spirit of an institution of
learning, or, as our army circles
put it, the morale, is directly proportioned to the student traditions. We have not been long at

Obituary.

Edgar A. Morgan, graduate
student in the Department of
Education, (lied of pneumonia on
February 5.
Koichi Morita, of Japan, a graduate student ill plant physiology,
botany and geology at this Uniersity, died suddenly at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital on Sunday,
February 8. Morita was a graduate of Tokio University and was
doing his second year's work at
Hopkins.
Dr. Livingston, professor of
plant physiology, considered him
a fine scholar, an indefatigable
worker and a thorough gentleman,
and says that he gave great promise of becoming a leader in botanical science. Morita's experimentation was in such shape that Dr.
Livingston and Mr. H. C. Diehl
plan to prepare a brief report of
the results of his experiments for
publication in the near future.
In the universities of South
America, subjects are commonly
studied only for a professional
end. The scholar studies natural
sciences only in the medical school
for their bearing on medicine, and
the social sciences only in the law
school for their bearing on jurisprudence. Hence the universities
generally contain only professional schools without any college of
liberal arts.
The United States is carrying
on two collossal experiments in
education. One is to conduct its
schools largely through the services of unmarried ladies who average three years' teaching before
they get married. The second is
to give education without religion.
The United States has yet to prove
that it will succeed in either or
both of these experiments.—Prof.
Sisson, University of Montana.

Thinks Hopkins is Dying of Dry Pot.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

February 14, 1920.
Sir—it was with extreme regret
that 1 heard of the resignation of
Dr. Slonimsky from the faculty
of the Department of Philosophy.
Helping to solve the greatest probkm before the country today—
that of labor—could not but make
a man more capable of bringing to
his classes a most valuable point
of view.
Universities have often been accused of being too secluded and
out of touch with the problems of
the world. Philosophy has lost
much of its erstwhile popularity
because it did not come in the
realm of "useful" studies. And
so when a professor who is combining practical work with his
teaching is allowed to resign it
appears inexcusable. The theory
of "splendid isolation" for universities is absurd.
Harvard is justifiably proud of
such of its men as Ripley, who has
been engaged in arbitrating labor
disputes for several years, and
Taussig, who has been called to
the Industrial Conference in
'Washington.
' Does Hopkins want only men
on its faculty who fit Shaw's characterization of a teacher: "A man
who can does, a man who can't
teaches." Or perhaps the powers
that be think that the faculty can
learn nothing except from the
books in the library.
I regard the fact that Dr. Slonimsky was not kept in the faculty on part time as another indication of what many of the
younger graduates believe—that
Hopkins has lost its traditional
vitality and is dying of dry rot.
Very truly yours,

A. L. HAMBURGER, 18.
Pleased With Editorials.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—I want to use a little of
your valuable space to express my
appreciation of your editorials.
One of their chief values is that
they are always very pertinent as
regards questionsdirectly affecting
Hopkins, and are always trying to
improve conditions that need
remedying. In BO many periodicals
of this kind the editorials are so
perfunctory that they are of little
• value. Your editorial on the Kessler petition deserves the commendation of every true Hopkins man.
E. R.
Yours sincerely,

QUACKS FROM A QUACK
Eurroa's Nom----George is very greatly
elated over the overwhelming success of
his own personal quack column, but he
fears that his sparkling and scintillating
satire is not received in the serious manner
In- which it is meant. He has, therefore,
applied • to THE NEWS-LETTER for permis• sion to preach a sermon in this week's
issue, and he sincerely hopes and trusts
that his efforts will not be in vain. Needless
to say his request was granted, and we submit for your approval a little talk by the
Rev. George Quack, D. 1).1

Brethren, if you may be termed
as such, I am going to take may
text this morning from the first
chapter of St. John, twenty-third
verse, "the voice of one crying in
the wilderness." The voice in
this case I take to .• be the poor
little innocent freshman who finds
himself deposited in the midst of
a large university, not knowing
which way to turn without encountering a soph's paddle. Just
a bit of advice to ye freshmen from
one who has been through the
mill and knows, you can't get any
more out of college life than you
put into it. Why, just the other
day Dr. Gilpin told me that
George Wagner's kid brother (I
can't think of his maiden name
right now) was in the midst of
making a concoction of silver nitrate by dissolving a dime in
nitric acid. "Doc," he says, "I
haven't got a dime, will two
nickels do?"
And then, freshmen, don't fool
away your precious hours of study
by going to the theatre- all the
time like Chauncey Wright does.
They tell me that he was summoned to his adviser not so long
ago to receive some paternal advice. "Lemme see your report,.
Mr. Wright," said Dr. Gilpin.
"Ahem, failed in two subjects,
didn't you? Damn pity you didn't
flunk in three, and then we
wouldn't have to bother with
you." Moral, don't do as I do,
do as I say should be did.
If you really and truly want to
make an honest-to-gosh success of
your college career commit some
crime worthy of publication in my
world-beating column. That done,
your fame is assured for generations to come; in other words, you
have burst into immortal print.
Like a little crowd of fellows in
Biology II have passed a bill
which states that the chap who
receives the lowest mark in a quiz
has to stand treat for the bunch.
For the last five times Mr. Frank
Smith has footed the bill, and for
this -unsurpassed record the other
biologists deem him worthy of a
little notoriety. They are right,
Mr. Smith; that, sir, is a deed
Worthy to place you before the
public eye.
. And in conclusion, let me tell
you, you didn't mind being paddled a bit for having your hands
in your pockets. To err is human
and to forgive divine, which goes
to prove that the sophomores are
not divine. Amen!

Preliminary trials for the selection of the representative of Johns

held on Wednesday and Thursday,

Warren Driver,'20; George Goetz,
'21; A. L. Langeluttig, '22, and
Leon Saiontz,'22. The trials were
judged by Dr. French and Mr.
Hammond. Their decision was
that Goetz, who spoke on "Free
Speech and Radicalism," should
have the honor and responsibility
of speaking at Lexington for
Johns Hopkins. In this contest,
which will be held on March 5,
'he will meet the orators of six
representative southern universities, including our old rivals in
debate, the University of Virginia
and the University of North Carolina.

CLUB HAS GOOD REHEARSAL
"Pep" Displayed by Musical Club To
Give a Concert on February 27-28,
and on March the 19th.

The first rehearsal of the Musical Clubs since the examinations'
quarantine was held as usual in
the Civil Engineering Hall on
February 9. The attendance was
good and the men made a strong
attack on the music for the spring
concerts. "Shorty" Defandorf reported that the treasury is in a
healthy condition at present, but
will need a little "dosing" within
the next month.
Hartman put the Glee Club
through a grilling practice and
ended by telling them that it was
one of the best rehearsals of the
year. He was especially pleased
with the control of the modulation in "Annie Laurie," and even
the C. E. night janitor said that,
"all yah needed to do was to close
yah eyes, an'—oh, boy !"
The Instrumental Club will use
the piano and traps with their
numbers for the rest of the season. The addition makes a great
improvement all around.
With "Mike" Bowers tickling
the ivories, the jazz orchestra,
with a new set of traps. is "raising Cain." Paul Wiggins is showing how to jazz a ukulele, and
"Shorty" Rankin and Vanneman
make things hum. On the whole,
Coulter is turning out an Instrumental Club Mitch is making a•
name for itself.
A concert will be given on February 27 or 28. But just wait till
March 19! The concert that night
at Towson High School A'ill be followed by a dance, so get ready
Musical Club men.

FACULTY NOTES
Dr. Burton E. Livingston, pro
fessor of plant physiology, and
director of the laboratory of plant
life at the Johns Hopkins University, has recently been elected
permanent secretary of the AmeriCa 11 Association for the Advancelima of Science, to take the place
of Dr. L. 0. Howard, who resigned
to take the presidency. Professor
Livingston will continue his work
in the University and plans to
spend about two days a week in
Washington, where he has his
office in the Smithsonian Institution.
Prof. Livingston is a S. B. graduate of the University of Michigan, 1898; fellow, University of
Chicago, 1899-1902; Ph. D., 1902;
assistant in plant physiology,
1902-04, and associate, 1905; collaborator, U. S. Bureau of Forestry, 1902; research fellow, New
York Botanical Garden, 1903;
Walker prize man, Boston Society of Natural History, 1904; soil
expert, in charge of the Division
of Fertility, U. S. Bureau of Soils,
1904-05; staff member, Department of Botanical Research, Carnegie Institution of Washington,
1906-09.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 17,

SLINGLUFF BEST FANCY DIVER

MRS. SPEARE MAKES ADDRESS

Swimming Team Suffers Second Defeat
—Columbia Better by Overwhelming Score —Hopkins Gets
Only. One Place.

"Russian Dramatists" Subject of Her
Talk to Literary Club—Emphasizes
Influence of Russian School.

The second lecture of a series
given under the auspices Of the
Literary Club was held Friday
evening, February 6, in the Mechanical Engineering Hall. Florence Lewis Speare addressed the
club on "Russian Dramatists and
the Modern Russian Stage." Mrs.
Speare, who has just been elected
president of the Drama League of
Baltimore, was well qualified to
lecture. She is a graduate of
Prof. George Pierce Baker's Workshop Theatre of Harvard and at
present is director of dramatics
at Goucher College. Mrs. Speare
is a dramatic writer herself, and
the vivid, colorful choice of words
and the interesting manner of
presentation made her lecture admirable and instructive.
Mrs. Speare spoke of the Russian stage as the world's leading
theatre where "all the arts are
gathered together in a poem of
beauty." Before the rise of the
Russian influence, the stage, both
in Europe and America, consisted
very largely in the presentation
of elaborate realistic scenes, which
fed the senses and made no appeal
to the imagination or the intellect. Suddenly a change came;
symbolism of the stage was born.
It was an attempt to symbolize
the soul of the drama in the setting. It is this symbolism in the
"mise en scene" which the Russian spirit demands—a symbolism
which is Oriental in barbaric brilliancy, vivid in passionate emotion and rich in temperamental
analysis. As colorists the Russians lead. America was intro
duce(' to the Russian spirit and
mood by the Russian ballet.
Leon Baskt is chief in creating
the "mounting of the play." He
uses lights, colors and music as
symbols to further the atmosphere
of the play. He is "intellectualizing scenery." This school of stage
artists give freest expression to the
imagination. There is grotesque
opulence and fairy delicacy. The
drama has been revolutionized. It
is far more than words; it is
scenes of pictures and symphonies
•of sounds. All the arts have been
concentrated to produce the
drama as exemplified in Russia.
In 1825 Russian drama was
born through the repression of

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team suffered its second defeat of
the season when it met and lost to
the Columbia team by the score
of 39-14 in the Baltimore Athletic
Club on Friday night, February 6.
The home team was able to will
but one first place and two seconds. Such a decisive defeat was
entirely unexpected and is attributed to the fact that few of
the Hopkins men were able to
practice during the week on account of the mid-year examinations.
Charlie Slingluff starred for
Hopkins, experiencing but little
difficulty in defeating the Columbia men in the fancy dive. Mabie,,
of the vistitors, was second and
Call, of Hopkins, third in this
event.
The first event, the 160-yard relay, was taken by Columbia, with
plenty to spare at the end. Garrigus and Chrystal, of the visiting
team, finished first and second in
the 40-yard dash, with Davidge
Rowland close behind them. In
the 220 yards, Polk, of Columbia,
led from the start, while "Bod"
Hall nosed the other New Yorke
out for second honors. Henry
Rowland could not quite catch
Everhard in the 100-yard swim
and had to be satisfied with second
place. Bernard, also of Columbia,
was third in this event.
Columbia was represented by
two plungers as expert as any seen
in Baltimore this year in flinch
and Mahaar, both of whom made
the whole pool, 60 feet, in less
than 40 seconds. The former won
the event with the excellent time
of 39 seconds. Gould, of the home
team, was third.
rhe Hopkins team is scheduled
to meet the University of Pennsylvania swimmers at the Baltimore Athletic Club at 8 o'clock
next Saturday night, February 21.
With regular practices, several
times this week, Captain Hall expects to have his team in a condition to make a much better
showing of itself, although Pennsylvania is represented ,by some
of the most expert swimmers in
the country.
